transcription.text: [APPLAUSE]
We made it.
Well, my voice didn't, but you guys did.
I just want to first thank the Theorem Foundation.
This is the first time a design track
is in a developers' conference.
Can we give them a hand?
A clap.
Awesome.
And we also want to say thank you to the developers who
have been so open and curious.
We had this UX audit.
It was so fun, such a high demand
that we had to turn people down and make a queue.
And so we're hoping to continue that post-defcon.
So watch out for those news.
And so I'm not really going to talk about the why of UX.
I think we're a little bit beyond that now.
But we're going to talk about the how.
I think it's important to know how UX is entering this field.
So how does Web3 look and act different than Web2?
How is the technology fundamentally
different for our generation?
How are we designing for the future?
These are all really great questions
that we're asking ourselves, which are really fun.
And so exciting things.
Honestly, we kind of-- this is our first award show.
And so obviously, it's a work in progress.
If you have feedback, we love feedback.
So please let me know.
Come up to me.
But we are-- if you didn't get a chance
to sign up this time, feel free to sign up next time.
Now you have a whole year to prepare.
So we're expecting some really great stuff for next year.
And so we want to talk about the criteria a little bit, right?
So we had a hard time coming up with something
that was inclusive, but here it is.
So first, ingenuity.
Is the solution clearly inventive or resourceful?
We want to see some creativity in some of these ideas.
And it's all a weighted criteria.
And so we also want to look for language and visual cues.
Are the action commands clear and easy to understand?
Usability, obviously, really important.
Is it easy to interact with?
User research.
Are these actions informed by research and insights?
I think we have some really amazing workshops
and some talks that talked about that.
And then accessibility.
Does it reduce the barriers to entry?
And so this is kind of what we came up with for this year.
And probably beyond we're going to continuously work on it.
And without further ado, I'd like
to say thank you to our judges who are amazing
and went through 85 submissions in like several hours.
So Samara Nakfor, who is the senior designer at IDEO.
Connie Yang, who is the design director at Coinbase,
and Dylan Field, who is the CEO and co-founder of Figma.
We really want to create a well-rounded panel
that we're not biased to any project,
but actually can give different insights.
So instead of just telling you guys we want to show--
and so without further ado, Dylan
is going to announce the first winner.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
[APPLAUSE]
So, hey.
And so for our first winner, we have the bounties network.
Yeah.
So I'd like to introduce Mark Bailin from the bounties
network to the stage.
We were so impressed with the bounties network
because they managed to tie crypto incentives
to real life action.
And also we were incredibly impressed
with the way that they were extremely thorough
throughout their entire product and how everything
was considered.
So without further ado, here he is.
Thank you so much.
Cool.
So-- oh, there we go.
Cool.
So when we first launched the bounties network a year ago,
and if you look at our GitHub commits,
the way we started was always with standard bounties.
It was always about building a protocol for bounties
on Ethereum that would be interoperable.
However, we realized fairly early on
that we would need to build a generalized product
and explore that would actually allow users to interact
with the bounties network.
And so this would also act as a testing ground.
And this is what we've been doing a lot for the last year,
is testing how bounties can be used on Ethereum.
And so we weren't incredibly happy when we first launched
that explore.
It was an MVP.
And we recognized that you probably
shouldn't be happy launching such an early product.
But we were lucky that we were able to get so much user feedback
really early on.
And this is user feedback about the user experience,
the details of--
there we go.
Maybe that'll start the video.
Maybe not.
OK.
We wanted to get user feedback about the user experience,
that users actually have to go through,
the different touch points that users have actually
outsourcing work.
Also, the different details of actually using ADAP,
the different primitives we have like an address,
or transactions, or gas, and trying
to figure out how we can abstract these for users
so that they don't even have to understand.
And hopefully they can learn about these concepts
without even realizing that they're learning.
And so as our team grew, we actually
started rebuilding things from scratch,
not only rebuilding our protocol and our caching layer,
but our explorer.
And so we actually built it in such a way
that we would hopefully-- it would be so modular and very
usable and extensible for any DAP in the ecosystem
to make it as easy as possible for anyone
to build a marketplace.
And so at the Bounties Network, all of our decisions
we try to make for our users.
Everything we do is in service of them
and to try to help them create more value.
So we were lucky enough that our hive of bees actually
has been consistently over the last year,
giving us a ton of feedback about how they liked our product,
what they didn't like.
And that is really what has fed into this new explorer.
And so without them, I want to sort of give them a thanks.
First is without them, we wouldn't have anything here.
We wouldn't know what we were building.
The next thanks I want to give is to the rest of the team.
A lot of them are sitting in that row over there.
Corwin Harrell, unfortunately, who
is our head of design, is not here,
who deserves yes a round of applause
for consistently advocating for users, yes.
But also, Will Vowinwava, our CTO,
who put the team on his back, actually building this product,
Matt and Matias, who joined us a little bit later
to help us sprint through the finish,
and Simona and Blair as well, who really fight this battle
on the front lines, talking to our users, gathering feedback.
And like I said, in having that inform this.
Next up, I want to take a special moment and thank my mom.
My mom has been our number one UX feedback tester since day
zero.
And we're really proud of our product,
and we think we've done a lot of good work.
But we also recognize that we are still failing the mom tests.
Moms can't use our product without hand holding.
And so we're about to run, for example, a project in Manila,
where we want users to clean up trash
and get to fulfill bounties for picking up trash.
The problem is that users have to onboard to an exchange,
adapt wallet, and then our product as well.
And so we've kind of realized that this is untenable,
that we can't ever achieve mainstream adoption
while this is still the case.
But at the same time, we're also very lucky
that the community is realizing this as well,
whether it's challenges with onboarding.
And we're lucky to be working with the meta transaction
group on actually fixing that problem,
whether it's the sort of solving education and onboarding
and working with ETH magicians and a lot of the different daps
who are there as well to help sort of have some consistency
around the language that we're using when we're onboarding
users to make it easier for people to actually join our community.
But also just to share as much as we can with all the other daps,
we've done a lot of user research and have hopefully
some lessons that we can share.
But also our component library, all the different buttons
and UI elements you see are completely open source
at components.bounties.network.
So if you guys want to build a dap and don't
want to worry about design, you can actually
reuse all of the stuff that we've already built, which
is also very important.
Finally, we're really happy that these awards actually exist.
They didn't exist last DevCon.
The number of design events last DevCon
was pretty minimal compared to this year.
And if you actually went to any of those awards,
you would see that they were all overflowing with people
who are all beginning to recognize that while scaling
is important, if we don't have any users actually
creating those transactions, scaling won't matter.
And so while we recognize that there's
a ton of work that needs to be done, not only with our product,
we have mobile responsiveness, not only with our product,
but also with all the different daps in the ecosystem.
We're excited because we realize that everybody
is collectively recognizing that this is an issue
and coming together to actually solve it together.
So thank you guys very much and thank you guys for the award.
Thanks so much.
Congratulations.
Kay, and then next up we have Samir.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
Thanks, Amy.
It's welcome, Itamar from Argent.
So what we really liked about Argent was--
yes, first.
[APPLAUSE]
What we really liked about what they did
is that they're trying to attack some of the bigger UX
problems in this space, namely wallet recovery without seeds
and without compromising on self sovereignty.
So I'll let Itamar say more about what they've done so far.
Thanks, Samir.
So first, thanks for the award.
Thanks, everyone.
I'm Itamar, one of the founders of Argent.
So the vision of Argent was really
to remove all friction to enable access to web 3.
And for that, we really started from a blank sheet
to taking all problems one by one.
As a result with Argent, you have no more seed phrase.
You don't have gas thanks to abstraction
with meta-transaction and our relayers.
And you can also use that to access in the future
all world of the centralized application.
We-- and also no more cryptic address.
That's a big point for us.
And no stress.
And all that in a fully decentralized way.
So if we continue the onboarding--
let's onboard at Argent, basically.
You start with a first step, which is to pick your ENS.
So we are very excited about that.
Every user of Argent gets a free ENS, Argent.xyz.
Once-- and thanks for the ENS team, if you are around.
So we are very excited about that.
Once you have picked your ENS, we
think about the stress about handling crypto today.
And so we enable users to get security alerts straight
so their preferred channel can be a phone, can be an email.
And we will monitor for them transactions.
And in K-ROS suspicious transaction,
we'll let them know about it.
We, of course, have the usual biometrics supported
by most devices.
And you are done with your onboarding.
You haven't even thought about seat phrases.
So let's talk about seat phrases.
For us, it's literally an anachronism.
For 20 years, we have been telling internet users
to not write down their password on the Post-It
and stick it on their screen.
And now for this new internet, we
are building a new internet while telling people
to write down on paper something even more critical
than a password.
So with Argent and our Guardian system,
you have no more seat phrases.
So the way it works-- so we have a smart contract base wallet.
And you already know of that wallet.
Your guardians do not have your private key.
You do not share that key.
But they have some rights on your account.
So a Guardian is any kind of user account on the blockchain.
And they can launch a recovery procedure.
So concretely, that means it can be friends family who
download Argent.
But you don't have to trust other people.
It can be yourself.
It's any private key.
You can take a hardware wallet.
You can take three hardware wallets.
And there will be a consensus.
And at any time, in case of issue,
you can recover your account.
We also have looked at the best solution for exchange.
Decentralized exchange don't have to be complicated.
So we are very excited about native integration
of Kiber networks, where it's probably one of the simplest
ways to exchange any type of token on your phone, one
tap, and you are done.
Then let's talk about transaction.
Transacting, it's stressful.
It's complicated.
And it's sometimes dangerous.
And what if someone takes control of the wallet?
What if someone gets access to your private key?
So at Argent, you define a daily limit at a smart contract
level.
Someone gets access to your phone.
In the current world, it's over.
Someone has access to your private key.
They will drain your account.
With Argent, the smart contract will
see that there is a large transfer being
triggered to an untrusted address.
Because obviously, you have never used that address.
You have never sent money there.
And it will delay the transfer by 24 hours.
You contact your guardians or pick up your hardware wallet.
You have time for that.
And you will freeze the wallet, launch, and recovery procedure.
And so obviously, you can whitelist addresses
so that you can transfer as much money as you want to an exchange
or prefer to your preferred address at any time.
We have also some little tricks here and there.
So for example, there are use cases
where you have to ask users to double check an address.
Critical situation, for example, a country recovery.
So in that case, what we do, we hash the address
into very, very easy to check emotic images.
You check the images, and you are done.
It's, again, a much more relaxing experience
when you think about public addresses.
So always wanted to have a slide like that, finally done.
So I mentioned in Arjun, you don't have to worry about gas.
You actually don't pay gas because we have meta-transaction.
We have an area.
Data laws, much more interesting to do other interesting things.
And so we are very excited to support universal login.
So you will be able to have a frictionless access to any data.
So how it works, you type your ENS.
You then get a QR code.
And basically what you are doing there,
you think about a Facebook login experience
but fully decentralized.
You tell your wallet, hey, I want to authorize that DAP key
to do something on my wallet, to give it some orders.
And so in that case, I've even set a security policy
so that DAP key is not the owner of the wallet.
They cannot do whatever they want.
In this case, I've said, OK, they can spend one day, third day.
At any time, I go in my wallet and I can revoke access.
So that's really how we have thought from A to Z
about the experience.
We're--
[APPLAUSE]
So what is maybe the most exciting part
is that we are live on the App Store.
So you go now to www.argent.xyz.
You will have links for iOS, for Android.
Today, you will be awaiting lists.
We are being really careful getting user bit by bit
as we want the all experience to be perfect.
But you can already reserve your free ENS.
So go for it straight away.
Since Amy hasn't cut me yet, I have another minute, maybe,
to thanks all the ecosystem.
I mean, there is the ENS team and Nick.
There is the Metacartel, the Kyber team.
I mean, that wouldn't be possible without all the work
that have been done by the entire ecosystem.
So thanks, everyone.
[APPLAUSE]
And next up, we have Connie, who's
going to announce our new winner.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
Hi, everyone.
I'm really excited to announce our last prize
for our last winner for our design prize.
And it goes to Blue Shift.
And I'd like to introduce Kane.
And one of the reasons that this is really impressive for us
to see as judges is that they really
get at the whole user journey.
It's not just the product, which is obviously super important,
but the experience of somebody trying to navigate what
is the world of crypto and blockchain for the first time.
And if we want to make this global,
we have to think about the people who
don't have access to exchanges the same way we do.
Is that without anymore?
Thank you.
This is pretty exciting for me.
We got the clicker.
I'll kind of step through it.
Can we pause it?
Yeah.
Oh, I don't know.
OK.
All right.
We're just going to walk through it.
So this is a live demo since we couldn't do a live demo.
So basically, we've got this platform here, which
is an iPad.
And it's running in 1,250 stores in Australia.
And it's live now.
So if you ever come to visit in Australia,
you can go and buy some crypto.
And basically, the way it works is you've got your Ether wallet.
So you've got QR code.
You scan it on the iPad.
You can walk into one of these stores.
And the system will detect the code.
And it will allow you to purchase Ether directly in store
for cash.
And this solves a lot of problems.
But one of the challenges we have, as you can imagine,
being in 1,250 retailers is that the people who
are operating this platform are not technically
sophisticated, right?
They're small business owners.
It needs to be super easy to use.
And so we've designed the system, basically,
to be as accessible as possible.
And-- oh, it's paused over there.
But OK.
So essentially, what happens is, customer walks in,
they choose how much they want to purchase.
The agent will put in, as it says,
they don't accept credit cards because it's cash-only service.
So that's an ugly screen, but it's there for a very good reason.
And the agent will process the transaction.
And they scan it into their point of sale system
to sync it up with the rest of their accounting.
And then the ETH is sent to the wallet of the user.
So this system has been in operation since about 2016.
We started the company in 2014.
And it took us a couple of years to find the right exchange
partners and what have you.
But I guess the interesting thing for me with BlueShift
is that we've probably now processed about 100,000 transactions.
So that's 100,000 real users in the real world
who've walked into a store and been able to get crypto.
And I think the even more exciting thing about this
is that while we have the ability to purchase
Bitcoin and ETH and a few other cryptocurrencies
over the counter, we actually want
this to be a distribution method for more than just buying crypto.
As you can imagine, a lot of the people who've been coming in
by crypto have been coming in for speculative purposes,
not necessarily for usage.
And so if you're out there and you're building something
that you want to get into people's hands,
whether it's a game or a DAP or something like that,
we really want to talk to you because certainly
in Australian other markets, as we expand,
we're going to be probably one of the easiest ways--
I mean, someone mentioned the mom test or mom test.
And for a new user coming in, yes, they've
got to have a wallet.
They've got to be able to get through all that stuff.
But actually purchasing ETH to be
able to do the first transaction can oftentimes--
you can download it out from the App Store and set up a wallet.
But getting that ETH to be able to get into the ecosystem
is quite hard.
And so this system allows you to get your users potentially
into the ecosystem very easily.
And we're super excited to work with any teams,
including we've got Detha here, who's one of our partners.
So anyone who's looking for distribution
who wants to get real world users who are not deep crypto
people who kind of get all the ins and outs, we're there.
So yeah, thanks very much.
Really appreciate the support.
It's awesome to see because we kind of sit in the middle
and we don't get as much exposure.
So the Blue Shift team is kind of in the background.
And so it's really validating to be given this award.
So thank you.
[APPLAUSE]
So we had the judges go through quite a bit of submissions.
And they had a hard time at the end.
But so we want to give some shout outs for some runner-ups,
Ergon, who just also for their design system
and their components that they just released,
crypto care for their kind of whimsical take on social impact,
and then status for their easy onboarding process.
And the--
[APPLAUSE]
And we want to thank known origin, who has actually provided
the trophy of this UX Awards.
It's a limited edition.
NFT, which all the winners will receive,
and this by the artist Martin Lucas Oster-Ochsikki.
So thank you guys all for coming.
And we can't wait for the submissions for next time.
[APPLAUSE]
[MUSIC PLAYING]
